items.description: River Thames and its tributaries from Days Lock to above Pangbourne

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Lady Brook, Ewelme Stream, Mill Brook, West Hagbourne Stream, Hakkas Brook, Cholsey Brook, Kibble Ditch

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but have been lowering on the River Thames. Levels on the upper Thames have fallen below threshold, but remain high downstream, particularly at Goring Lock. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the next few days. No further rain is expected today, 4 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high on the lower River Churn as a result of recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue in the Cerney Wick area today, 4 October 2024. No further rain is expected today. River levels are expected to remain high along the river today.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff will be out in the river catchment today checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Datchet to Shepperton Green
River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the weekend which may cause rivers to rise again.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: River Thames and tributaries from Buscot Wick down to Kings Lock
items.message:
Further property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels are high along much of the upper River Thames as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Levels on the upper Thames have fallen below threshold, but remain high downstream of Radcot, particularly at Shifford and Eynsham Locks. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue. No further rain is expected today, 4 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is expected.

Flood warnings are in force for the River Ray at Islip and for the Murcott area. River levels are high but stable on the River Ray, however, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 4 October 2024. No further rain is expected today, with a more settled period over the coming days. River levels are currently stable but are expected to remain high over the next few days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.

items.message:

No further flooding of roads and low lying land are expected but standing water may still be seen for some days.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are still rising in response to recent heavy rainfall within the catchment. This information is correct as of 14:30 on Friday 4th October. 

The causeway at Earith has approximately 36 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has 118 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 138 centimetres of water on the road.  Due to uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

We will update this message by 8am, Saturday 05/10/2024

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are high on the River Coln and tributaries as a result of recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Fossebridge area. No further rain is expected today, 4 October 2024, with a more settled period over the coming days. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 5 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are still high but starting to fall on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Friday 4 October.
No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.
We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
Friday 4 October and Saturday 5 October are forecast to remain dry. Further rainfall is possible on Sunday 6 October.
As river levels remain high and we are not expecting much change in the level at the Staines Moor gauge, this message will continue to be updated once per day. 
This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Saturday 5 October, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 16:15 on 04/10/24, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are peaking today. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 192 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:30 on 04/10/24, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

items.description: B1040 Thorney to Whittlesey Road to the South of the River Nene
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. The Whittlesey Wash flood storage reservoir is being operated to protect nearby communities from flooding. The rising levels in the Wash will result in flooding of the B1040 road. Whilst the Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority may close the B1040 for safety reasons. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 05/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are falling slowly at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. So the risk of flooding remains throughout today, 04/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. 
No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. 
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides coinciding with high flows from upstream. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon 04/10/24, at 15:45 and is forecast to reach between 4.70 - 5.00 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected early tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, at 04:00 and is forecast to reach between 4.70 - 5.00 metres. Therefore, the river could overtop banks again and flood low lying land. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Sow and River Penk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels are falling at the Milford river gauge, as a result of recent persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Bank Road alongside the River Nene, east of Peterborough and west of Dog-in-a-Doublet Sluice
items.message: River levels in the Peterborough area remain high on the River Nene. During periods of high tide the River Nene will be unable to discharge into the sea, resulting in tide lock conditions. This is likely to lead to localised flooding of the North Bank Road, between Peterborough and Rings End throughout today, Friday 4 October 2024 and into tomorrow. Whilst this Flood Warning is in force, the Local Authority will close North Bank Road. Diversionary routes will be put in place and further updates will be available through local media. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. We are closely monitoring the situation and this message will be updated by 17:00 on 05/10/2024, or before, if the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels are high but beginning to fall at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following the recent heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
Further rainfall is forecast this weekend that may cause rivers to rise again. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am on 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday 05/10/24.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   

No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Shardlow and Willington river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible until 05/10/2024. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.

No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 05/10/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 18:00 this evening, 04/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message:
River levels are now falling on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is still possible through Friday and into Saturday. Property flooding is not expected.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Friday onwards and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 05/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are steadily falling. The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue flood alerts and warnings when necessary.

items.description: Burton Trent
items.message:
River levels are falling at the Croxall river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Trent between Kings Bromley to Clay Mills including Burton upon Trent.    
No further rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are high but falling across the upper River Great Ouse. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. 

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook. 

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will push levels up again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: River Tove in Northamptonshire
items.message:
River levels are high but falling. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. 

Areas most at risk are around the River Tove between Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook and the Stoke Bruerne Marina. 

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week, further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. Areas most at risk are around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield.  The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week, further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 5pm, Friday 04/10/24.

items.description: Middle Nene

floodArea.county: Cambridgeshire, North Northamptonshire, Peterborough, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River levels in the River Nene remain high as a result of recent rainfall in the Middle Nene area, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that further flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued.  We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 05/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message:
River levels are falling slowly at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall, . So the risk of flooding remains throughout today, 04/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington. 
No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.
Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/10/24 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message:
River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Levels are starting to fall but floodwater from upstream will cause levels in increase again in the next  few days. Flooding is still possible. 

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but the weather forecast is unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: Middle Avon Rugby to Bidford
Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall, a peak of floodwater has passed through Turvey and will flow through the system. This peak is lower than those seen in late September. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. 

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton. The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will push levels up again. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but steady on the Chertsey Bourne following a period of sustained rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected today, 04/10/24, especially in the areas closest to the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Mythe Bridge river gauge because of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.  
No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high for several days.    
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   
This message will be updated by 4pm on Friday, 04/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This alert is no longer in force due to receding levels and an improving outlook. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and re-issue the alert if required.

items.description: River Ivel in Hertfordshire and Central Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are now falling along the Ivel. The peak of floodwater passed through Blunham yesterday evening. Flooding is still possible for the next few days.  

Areas most at risk are around the River Ivel from Langford to Blunham, including the rivers Purwell, Hiz, Flit and Hit. 

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but the weather forecast is unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will push levels up again. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: River Wreake in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Brentingby Dam river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 05/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Idle in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast. 

We continue to monitor the situation. 

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Central Bedfordshire, Beds Borough and Cambridgeshire from Wyboston to Brampton
items.message:
River levels remain high but are slowly falling. Flooding is still possible for the several days as floodwater moves down the catchment from upstream of Bedford. 

Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Wyboston to the south of Brampton, including Duloe Brook, Hen Brook and Fox Brook. 

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but the weather forecast is unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.message:
River levels remain high. They are currently falling but will increase again as a peak of floodwater flows down from upstream of Bedford, this peak of floodwater is lower than that seen 28-30th September. Flooding is still possible for the next few days. 

Areas most at risk are Wyboston Lakes, School Lane in Eaton Socon, Hardwick Road and Springbrook in Eynesbury, The Paddock and Crosshall Road in Eaton Ford and River Terrace, Priory Lane, Chandlers Wharf, Brook Street, Church Street and Browns Square in St Neots. 

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 

We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Saturday 05/10/2024.

items.description: River Thame from Chiselhampton to Drayton St Leonard
items.message:
This flood warning has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The flood warning for the area has now been removed. However, a flood alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land. No rainfall is predicted until Sunday 6 October 2024. River levels are expected to continue falling but remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring river levels and will re-issue this warning if required. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Ray for Islip
items.message:
Property flooding is possible.

River levels are high but steady on the River Ray. Therefore flooding of properties, low lying land and roads is expected to continue this evening, 4 October 2024. Areas most at risk are properties closest to the river in Islip and surrounding villages. River levels are expected to remain steady over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water and do not drive along flooded roads. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to continue slowly falling over the coming days, but will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid contact with flood water and do not drive along flooded roads. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 4 October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Welland

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, Old River Welland, Maxey Cut

items.message: River levels on the River Welland remain high as a result of recent rainfall, which has led to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 05/10/2024, or before if the situation changes.

The forecast is dry today and tomorrow but unsettled from Sunday into next week. Further rainfall will keep levels high or push them up again. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Lower River Rother
items.message:
This flood alert is being removed as levels on the Lower River Rother have returned to normal range following Monday’s heavy rainfall.
Whilst levels at Woodhouse Mill remain elevated, they have been continuing to fall through the week and are now below levels of concern, though standing water may still remain.
We are continuing to manage the levels at Woodhouse Ings and will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this flood alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: River Rother at Woodhouse Mill
items.message:
This flood warning is being removed as levels on the River Rother at Woodhouse Mill have reduced considerably following heavy rain earlier this week. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water may still remain.
No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days and levels are expected to continue to fall slowly.
We are continuing to manage the levels at Woodhouse Ings and will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this flood warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

We are continuing to manage the levels at Woodhouse Ings and will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this flood warning if necessary.

items.description: River Soar at caravan parks near Barrow upon Soar
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  The Flood Warning for the area has now been removed.  However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
